Staff Writer Jun 21, 2025 Jun 21, 2025 Comments Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save It‚Äôs impressive that Crazy Horse Saloon & Grill in Nevada City is celebrating 60 years of business, but those six decades are only a mere fraction of the history of the building, said to be erected in 1862. Kate Anderson took over the popular joint in 2019, and has continued the tradition of live music, libations, and food she is proud to see come out of her kitchen. Tyler Blue has held the role of Music Director since 2013. When he began his role at the club/bar/restaurant, he took it upon himself to learn more about the rich history of the building itself. ‚ÄúI went to the Historical Society Museum and looked into all the records and it‚Äôs a rich history as you can imagine,‚Äù Blue said. ‚ÄúThe building itself (reads) 1862, so we say it‚Äôs been around since then, but the records don‚Äôt go before 1885 because of fires at that time. It was initially J.J. Jackson‚Äôs General Store and then it went through many different incarnations. Then Ray Dallugge bought it and turned it into the Chief Crazy Horse Inn in 1965.‚Äù ‚ÄúI had only been here once before when Ray still owned it, and honestly I don‚Äôt really have any memory of it at that point,‚Äù Anderson recalls. Her best friend Terra Saxton bought the business in the 2010s, eager to reopen this space that had seen such success. For a brief period, it was known as Crazy Cow Frozen Yogurt, a venture which lasted all but nine months, Anderson said. ‚ÄúTerra wanted to reopen it,‚Äù Anderson explained. ‚ÄúThis was something she always wanted to do. I started working with her and helping her reopen it and working for her for seven or eight years bartending and it was kind of just this transfer. She wanted to sell it and I think we always slightly discussed me taking it over, but it wasn‚Äôt always necessarily real until it became real when she was really ready to let it go.‚Äù Anderson said by the time she bought Crazy Horse, she knew it inside and out. It was a natural move for her to make when Saxton was ready to sell. Crazy Horse is, at least until about 9:00 p.m., family friendly, with many patrons joining for live music, trivia nights, and other events. Blue doesn‚Äôt take lightly the history of the building and what it has meant to the community over the past 60 years. ‚ÄúWe consider ourselves stewards of a very important historical landmark,‚Äù said Blue. ‚ÄúWe love hearing stories from our patrons about how important this place is to them, and countless stories of people who went here on their first date and they are now married, decades later. We love hearing about all the different eras from people riding motorcycles or horses into the bar, to even when there were stripper poles in here. There‚Äôs all sorts of traditions, and then new traditions. We consider it a living, breathing part of Nevada City history.‚Äù Anderson said keeping up not only a successful business but maintaining an over-100 year old building is a work in progress. ‚ÄúIt takes a beating daily,‚Äù Anderson said. ‚ÄúWe did the marquees and we have redone the floors three times. But really it‚Äôs just upkeep and updating, finding projects and ways we can make it better.‚Äù ‚ÄúKate is a very detail-oriented owner, and she makes a point of always fine-tuning things and improving things,‚Äù Blue added. The Crazy Horse has also solidified itself‚Äîin large part to Blue‚Äôs expertise‚Äîas a music venue, though a small one. The room only has a maximum capacity of 108 individuals, so if there is an act you really want to see, you better act fast. Blue said that nationally touring acts have complimented the venue on its sound and lighting program. Without the staff, Anderson said, Crazy Horse would be nothing. ‚ÄúThe staff and the people that put their blood, sweat, and tears into this place is huge,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe all take care of each other and you can feel it throughout. It was always really important for me to have people come in and recognize the staff or the bartenders or Tyler, and just know that we are kind of a family and we‚Äôre all still here.‚Äù Echoed Blue: ‚ÄúWe put a lot of care into the staff and making sure we have an optimal team to run this place as much as it can be. I have been at the door greeting people for virtually every show we‚Äôve had since March 2013. I can‚Äôt believe it, but I walk into this place every weekend and I feel better instantly.‚Äù While Crazy Horse doesn‚Äôt have any particular event to commemorate the 60th anniversary, they believe their establishment sets itself apart from any other downtown eatery or bar. What they have to offer, Blue said, is unique and captures the spirit of Nevada City. ‚ÄúThis place wears many hats,‚Äù Blue said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a sports bar, it‚Äôs a bar, it‚Äôs a restaurant, it‚Äôs a music venue, and it‚Äôs a gathering point. There‚Äôs fun for the whole family here. There‚Äôs a good meal, including late night dining. There‚Äôs good shows every weekend. We are okay with people who want to call us a dive bar but we also consider ourselves a more sophisticated establishment and we just want people to feel comfortable here.‚Äù Anderson is clearly grateful for the support she has received from the community and her customers‚Äîmany of them regulars. She is also proud to usher in the 61st year of Crazy Horse Saloon & Grill and add to its rich history. ‚ÄúI feel honored,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI feel like this is the period of time in the life of the Crazy Horse that I get to help run it and help it stay alive until the next person comes, and hopefully they do the same thing. Hopefully we will have a 100th anniversary one day, and we can be telling the same stories and it will still be a music venue and thriving, a place where people can come and dance with their community.‚Äù Crazy Horse Saloon & Grill is at 230 Commercial Street in Nevada City. For more information visit crazyhorsenc.com or call 530-265-4000. To conta ct Staff Writer Jennifer Nobles please email jnobles@theunion.com .
